data.question: What is the role of hydroxyl groups within the pores of NOTT-300 in binding CO2 and SO2?
data.answer: The hydroxyl groups bind CO2 and SO2 through the formation of O5C(S)5O(d2)...H(d1)-O hydrogen bonds, which are reinforced by weak supramolecular interactions with C-H atoms on the aromatic rings of the framework.

data.question: Is the adsorption of CO2 and SO2 in NOTT-300 reversible?
Does NOTT-300 exhibit higher selectivity for CO2 over other gases like CH4, CO, N2, H2, O2, and Ar?
What is the isosteric heat of adsorption range for CO2 in NOTT-300?
How does NOTT-300 compare to amine-functionalized materials in terms of CO2 binding energy?
data.answer: NOTT-300 has a moderate isosteric heat of adsorption (27-30 kJ mol-1) compared to higher values (40-90 kJ mol-1 for physisorption; 85-105 kJ mol-1 for chemisorption) observed in amine systems.

data.question: What is the significance of the cis configuration of m2-OH groups in NOTT-300?
data.answer: The cis configuration of m2-OH groups is responsible for the chirality and rigidity of the framework in NOTT-300, leading to the formation of square-shaped channels with hydroxyl groups protruding into them.

What is the role of the second CO2 site identified in NOTT-300.3.2CO2?
data.answer: The second CO2 site interacts principally with the first CO2 through dipole interaction, forming an edge-on intermolecular CO2 network along the pore channel.

data.question: What is the role of the second SO2 site identified in NOTT-300.4SO2?
data.answer: The second SO2 site, identified as SO2(II), interacts with SO2(I) through O(d2)...S(d+) dipole interactions, stabilizing an SO2(I,II) intermolecular chain within the channel.
